bestBHT.bht: Jesus responds to the devil's temptation by emphasizing that testing God is not the same as trusting God. He quotes Deuteronomy 6:16 to highlight this point, pointing out that we should not put God to the test. By using these quotes from Deuteronomy, Jesus asserts his authority over all creation and highlights that he is not only the Lord's servant, but also the Lord himself.

Marvin Vincent: It is said. For Matthew's it is written, Matthew 4:7. Luke omits Matthew's again. See Matthew 4:7.
Archibald T. Robertson: Jesus points out to the devil that testing God is not trusting God." (Plummer)
Each time he uses Deuteronomy against the devil."
John Gill: Thou shalt not tempt the Lord thy God.
Jehovah may be called the Lord his God, as he is his creator and governor.
He [Jesus] is God over all; over all principalities and powers, good and bad, by whom all are created, and in whom all consist.

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus responds to the devil's temptation by pointing out that testing God is not the same as trusting God. He consistently uses quotes from Deuteronomy to counter the devil's tactics. In this instance, Jesus quotes Deuteronomy 6:16 to emphasize that we should not put God to the test. This shows that Jesus is not only the Lord's servant, but also the Lord himself, having authority over all creation.

Jesus responds to the devil's temptation by emphasizing that testing God is not the same as trusting God. He quotes Deuteronomy 6:16 to highlight this point, pointing out that we should not put God to the test. By using these quotes from Deuteronomy, Jesus asserts his authority over all creation and highlights that he is not only the Lord's servant, but also the Lord himself.

Jesus, in responding to the devil's temptation, makes an important point about trusting God and not putting Him to the test. By quoting Deuteronomy 6:16, Jesus reminds us that testing God is not a display of faith but rather a lack of trust. His use of scripture against the devil demonstrates his deep knowledge of the Word and his understanding of its application in various situations. Therefore, we are reminded to place our full trust in God and not to test Him or doubt His abilities.

Jesus redirects the devil's temptation by emphasizing the importance of trust in God. He points out that testing God is not a demonstration of faith, as shown in the quote by Plummer. By quoting Deuteronomy 6:16, Jesus affirms the idea that we should refrain from testing God. This highlights his extensive knowledge of Scripture, as mentioned in the commentary. Ultimately, this verse reminds us of the significance of complete trust in God and not trying to challenge or doubt His authority.

Jesus demonstrates his reliance on Scripture by quoting Deuteronomy 6:16 in response to the devil's temptation. This exchange emphasizes the importance of trusting God instead of testing Him, as mentioned by the quote from Plummer. Jesus's use of the Word of God serves as a powerful reminder that our faith lies in complete trust in God's sovereignty. His deep knowledge of Scripture enables him to effectively counter the devil's temptations, highlighting the significance of knowing and applying God's Word in our lives.
